newsitem.title: VENEZUELA: Venezuela 6-month TEM yields rise to 17.80 pct.
newsitem.headline: Venezuela 6-month TEM yields rise to 17.80 pct.

text.p: Yields on Venezuelan benchmark six-month TEMs VE6MTMA=RR rose 32 basis points to 17.80 percent in Wednesday's auction, according to a calculation by Reuters that uses the Central Bank formula.

The Central Bank said it sold 70 billion bolivars of 177- day "monetary stabilization", or TEM, bills with a 17.48 percent coupon for a price of 99.85 pct. At last week's auction the six month notes yielded 17.48 percent

The bank also sold 15 billion bolivars of 266-day notes VE9MTMA=RR with a 17.85 percent coupon at a price of 98.66 percent, and 15 billion bolivars of 358-day notes VE1YTMA=RR with a 18.24 percent coupon at an average price of 97.63 percent.
Yields for these notes fell 55 basis points to 19.93 percent for the 266-day bills, and six basis points to 21.13 percent for the 358-day TEMs.
The weekly TEM bill auctions are the Central Bank's principal tool of monetary policy, used to restrict liquidity and establish a benchmark for wider interest rates.
